DOCNAME: CASE OF NOVOTNÝ v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life (Article 8-1 - Respect for private life)
JUDGES: Aleš Pejchal;Armen Harutyunyan;Kristina Pardalos;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Pauliine Koskelo;Ksenija Turković
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .
CARDINAL . In DATE he had a sexual relationship with a woman who gave birth to a daughter , PERSON , on DATE .
CARDINAL . As the applicant denied that he was the father , PERSON ’s legal guardian brought proceedings on her behalf in ORG ( okresní soud ) for a declaration of paternity .
CARDINAL . After giving birth to PERSON , but before initiating the aforementioned proceedings , the mother married another man .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the applicant was PERSON ’s father and ordered him to contribute to her maintenance .

CARDINAL . The court reached its finding after hearing evidence from several witnesses . It also had regard to documentary evidence and took into consideration the results of a blood test known as a “ bio - hereditary test ” ( dědicko - biologická zkouška ) . In addition , it established that the applicant had had intercourse with the mother sometime CARDINAL and DATE before PERSON ’s birth . In such cases , a presumption of paternity arose under LAW , unless there were clear grounds to rebut the presumption . Another man had also had intercourse with the mother at the crucial time , however , the blood test established that he was not the father .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an appeal with ORG ( krajský soud ) and requested another expert opinion . ORG denied the request because the facts had been proved to a sufficient degree . It eventually upheld the judgment of ORG on DATE , which became final on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant requested that ORG ( GPE státní zástupce ) challenge his paternity in court . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE he was informed that the requirements of LAW to initiate such proceedings had not been met . PERSON , by that time an adult , did not want to challenge paternity , it was not in her interests and the applicant had not produced any expert evidence credibly disproving it .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and PERSON underwent a DNA examination . The resulting report of DATE unequivocally confirmed that the applicant was not PERSON ’s father .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted a new request to ORG to challenge his paternity in court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Prosecutor General informed the applicant that the determination of his paternity had been decided by ORG under LAW and that therefore the prosecution service could not initiate proceedings under LAW of LAW . ORG only had that specific competence as regards statutory presumptions of paternity under LAW and CARDINAL of LAW . When paternity had been established by a judicial declaration under LAW and the judgment had come into legal force , as in the applicant ’s case , the law did not provide for any possibility to challenge it .

CARDINAL . Relying on his rights under LAW , the applicant lodged a constitutional complaint ( ústavní stížnost ) against ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE . He maintained that he had proved that he was not PERSON ’s biological father and requested that ORG ( GPE PERSON ) order the Prosecutor General to initiate proceedings and challenge his paternity . He also argued that Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW were unconstitutional .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . It noted that his paternity had been established by a judicial decision which had come into legal force and stated , inter alia , that the competence of ORG could only apply if all the legal requirements had been fulfilled , which was not , however , the applicant ’s case .
